content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China wants to make a deal and that he has no doubt about it, while he added China's signals show it wants to and that it will probably happen at the right time. (Newswires)

China's State Planning Commission Vice Chairman said the trade dispute is denting foreign manufacturing firms in China and that China will protect legal investment rights of foreign firms in the country. (Newswires)

Chinese press published commentary that stated the US should stop distorting facts after China's white paper and that the distortion of facts has been disappointing, while it blamed US for backtracking three times and suggested the US should shoulder "sole and entire responsibility for the severe setback to consultations". (Xinhua)

Chinese Global Times Editor said more than one Chinese key department are collecting experts' opinion on further countermeasures against US suppression. (Twitter) Huawei cut its orders to key suppliers following the US blacklisting and downgraded its forecast for H2 shipments by 20% to 30%. (Nikkei)

 

UK/EU

  • UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (May) 51.0 vs. Exp. 50.6 (Prev. 50.4). (Newswires) 
  • EU Retail Sales (Apr) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.9%, Rev. 2.0%) 
  • EU Markit Services PMI (May F) 52.9 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.5) 
  • EU Markit Composite PMI (May F) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.6 (Prev. 51.6) 
  • German Markit Services PMI (May F) 55.4 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.0) 
  • German Markit Composite PMI (May F) 52.6 vs. Exp. 52.4 (Prev. 52.4)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 6.771M vs. Exp. -0.849M (Prev. -0.282M). (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC is determined to bring down inventories and restore investment, while he added that they will take a flexible approach in the approaching months and that OPEC+ will take economic bearishness into account at the next meeting. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Beige Book stated the US economic activity expanded at a modest pace from April through mid-May and was a slight improvement from prior period, while business contacts reported concerns about international trade tensions across sectors such as manufacturing and agriculture. Furthermore, US manufacturing reports were generally positive although some noted slowing activity, employment continued to rise nationwide and prices continued to rise at a modest pace. (Newswires)

Fed's Brainard (voter) said she is prepared to adjust policy to sustain expansion and that trade conflict is a downside risk to the US economy. Brainard added she will be paying close attention to the payroll numbers to see how healthy the labour market is and that interest rates are likely to be lower than what people are used to in prior economic downturns. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (voter) said he still thinks the fundamentals are solid in the US economy and that it would be prudent to take a look at our setting for monetary policy as we do at every meeting, while he is a bit nervous about weak inflation. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter) said he prefers to be patient and let events unfold, while he added it is too early to make judgments on rates and that a rate cut at this moment would add stimulus to a neutral stance which the Fed is currently in the neighbourhood of. (Newswires)

Mexican President AMLO is optimistic that an agreement on US-Mexican trade can be reached today and was said to have received an official list of proposed retaliatory tariffs that could be imposed if the US follows through with its tariffs. (Newswires)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said US tariffs on Mexico may not have to go into effect. In related news, White House officials said the administration is "dead serious" about tariffs if nothing can be done to prevent migrant surge, while the White House sees trade with Mexico as critically important but added that "national security comes first". (Newswires)

US Senate Finance Chief Grassley predicts that the US will not impose the Mexican tariffs and stated that Mexico is going into talks with a "long list of things" to offer to avert the tariffs. Furthermore, other reports stated that US talking points in the Mexico tariff meetings include asylum cooperation, stopping trafficking networks, border enforcement and maintaining or increasing immigration detentions, while Mexico reportedly will make its own demands in talks with the US in which they will seek funds from US for development, demand that arms cease to criminal cartels and will not accept a "safe third country status" that forces asylum claimants to seek refuge in Mexico. (Newswires)

  • US ADP National Employment (May) 27.0k vs. Exp. 180.0k (Prev. 275.0k, Rev. 271.0k); lowest since March 2010. (Newswires) 
  • US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI (May) 56.9 vs. Exp. 55.5 (Prev. 55.5)
  • US Markit Services PMI Final (May) 50.9 (Prev. 50.9)
  • US Markit Comp Final PMI (May) 50.9 (Prev. 50.9)

 

MARKET RECAP

Salesforce.com (CRM) moved higher at the open after the firm reported earnings that beat on bottom line expectations and raised guidance higher for FY20. Brown-Forman Corp (BF.B) caught a bid after the firm also reported strong earnings, beating on the top and bottom lines. United Health Corp (UNH) was up after the healthcare provider raised its dividend. Ford (F) fell on news that Chinese subsidiary Changan Auto would be fined by Chinese regulators for violating anti-monopoly law. Boeing (BA) momentarily popped higher as news emerged that the aircraft maker is in talks with airlines from China for a 100-jet sale, but the move quickly reversed with sources stating that US-China trade discussions are complicating talks. Apple (AAPL) advanced, supported by CEO Tim Cook comments, where he said he doesn't see China targeting Apple in the trade dispute and the news that the company will ask developers to position a new "Sign on with Apple" button in iPhone and iPad apps which will be placed above rival buttons from Alphabet's Google and Facebook. Walmart (WMT) shares were up despite calls from Democratic Presidential Candidate Bernie Sanders pushing for higher wages for its workers. Campbell Soup (CPB) jumped higher after the firm posted strong earnings and raised FY guidance. Facebook (FB) lagged the market, under pressure amid news that investors are calling for Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to be replaced as chairman by an independent director. S&P 500 0.8% at 2826, NASDAQ-10 0.8% at 7221, Dow Jones 0.8% at 25540.

The Treasury curve steepened on Wednesday. After a grim ADP report, money markets priced 66% probability of three rate cuts in 2019, although this pricing was pared back after a solid non-manufacturing ISM report, which augurs well for the employment situation report due Friday. There were reports that accounts were buying the dip after dovish Brainard comments. At settlement, major curve spreads were wider at settlement, with the 2s30s spread at the highest level in over a year. US T-note futures (M9) settled 1+ ticks higher at 126-20+.

US MARKET WRAP - 05 JUNE 2019: Weak ADP, solid non-mfg ISM; doubts grow over Mexico tariff deal
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, dollar up, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: ADP big miss; Solid non-mfg ISM; Bearish DOE inventory report; Trump reiterates Mexican threat; dovish Fedspeak.

* COMING UP: AU Trade Balance, GE Industrial Orders, EU Revised Q1 GDP, ECB Rate Decision, US International Trade, Labour Costs & Productivity Revised, ECB Macro Projections, CA Ivey PMI, BoJ’s Kuroda and Fin Min Aso, BoE’s Carney, ECB’s Draghi speaks after rate decision, Fed’s Kaplan, Williams.

* MEXICO: Ahead of meetings between the US and Mexican delegations in Washington (meeting occurring in US afternoon trade, with Mexican officials set to give a press conference after 1800 EDT - talking points include: asylum cooperation, stopping trafficking networks, border enforcement, and maintaining or increasing immigration detentions) there were further constructive comments from Mexican President AMLO, which were then reinforced by the usually hawkish trade advisor Navarro, who said that tariffs on Mexico might not even go into effect. There has been increasing chatter form some in the GOP, coming out against Trump’s potential tariffs on Mexico. However, US President Trump continued the punchy rhetoric, stating that If Mexico does not take measures to control migrants, the tariffs will be implemented. As such, while a week ago, the consensus view was more hopeful that tariffs could be avoided, analysts are now preparing for the possibility that they will be enacted on 10th June. SGH Macro, a consultancy, for instance, argued that it was now highly likely that Trump would defy the resistance from some in the GOP, and deliver on his threats, in a sign of continued dissatisfaction with the measures the Mexican government is expected to propose. Finally, sources said Mexico will be making its own demands in talks with the US, seeking funds from US for development, as well as demanding that arms cease to criminal cartels, and Mexico will not accept "safe third country status"; the demands are likely to be a contentious topic with the Trump administration, and some analysts suggested that the chances of a deal had diminished.

* FED: Fed’s Kaplan (non-voter) managed to cause a few jitters in early trade after stating his preference for the FOMC to be patient and see how the situation unfolds, saying it was too early to make a judgement on rates. The comments might have found traders off-guard; although he is a non-voter this year, Kaplan is considered a dove, and as such, his call for patience is slightly at odds with building expectations that the Fed will cut rates in 2019. Fed’s Evans (voter) who yesterday sounded quite a dovish note, today intimated that every Fed meeting was live, adding that he was a little nervous about inflation developments. Evans also suggested that there were “insurance” reasons to talk about policy; Clarida this week also noted that the FOMC has enacted “insurance” rate cuts in the past, and Evans remarks are another voice in that direction. Governor Brainard (voter) said she was prepared to adjust policy in order to sustain the expansion, noting trade conflicts presented downside risks to the economy.

* BEIGE BOOK: There was increased focus on the Beige Book after Fed chair Powell’s comments on Tuesday. However, the headline sterilised the scarier phrasing of the report. The Beige Book stated that US economic activity expanded at a modest pace from the April-May survey period, a slight improvement over the previous report. However, business contacts reported concerns about international trade tensions across sectors such as manufacturing and agriculture. Some slowing in manufacturing activity was reported, by manufacturers were generally positive, as was the economic outlook for the coming months. Ahead of payrolls this week, the Beige Book stated that employment continued to rise nationwide, wage pressures remained subdued, although consumer spending reports were mainly positive.

* US/CHINA: There were few positives regarding US/China relations on Wednesday; China’s Xinhua published commentary criticising the US response to China’s white paper as disappointing, whilst reiterating China’s claim that the US is to blame for the breakdown in talks. China’s Global Times Editor then hinted that potential Chinese counter measures are in the pipeline: saying more than one Chinese key departments are collecting experts' opinion on further countermeasures against US “suppression”. Finally, reports emerged suggesting that the US is poised to sell tanks and weapons worth USD 2bln to Taiwan, a move likely to irritate China.

* ITALY: Italian political watchers shifted their eyes away from domestic political drama (after Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio seemingly made up on Tuesday) back to the country’s debt related confrontation with the EU on Wednesday. Following Tuesday reports that Italian Deputy PM’s Salvini and Di Maio had discussed the option of breaching the EU’s 3% budget deficit rule, news emerged that the European Commission are to begin the infringement process against the Italian government. German Finance Minister Scholz took a seemingly tougher stance on the issue, saying the rules-based procedure of the EU and good talks are the correct way to deal with Italy which contrasted somewhat with EU's Moscovici, who said the European Commission's door remains open to avoid disciplinary procedure against Italy. Italy’s Deputy PM Di Maio later commented that the government will not change position on its pension reform, which was followed by reports that Italy could nominate Italian Finance Minister Tria for a Europe Commission job, a move which would throw a wrench into the post European elections process of choosing who will get the European top jobs.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 1+ TICKS HIGHER AT 126-20+: The Treasury curve steepened on Wednesday. After a grim ADP report, money markets priced 66% probability of three rate cuts in 2019, although this pricing was pared back after a solid non-manufacturing ISM report, which augurs well for the employment situation report due Friday. There were reports that accounts were buying the dip after dovish Brainard comments. At settlement, major curve spreads were wider at settlement, with the 2s30s spread at the highest level in over a year.

* US ADP PAYROLLS: ADP National Employment Data came in at just 27k, well below the expected 180k and last month’s 271k (which incidentally revised lower from 275k), the worst print since September 2010. Pantheon Macroeconomics comments that “payroll growth was bound to slow in May, following April’s unexpected strength, but this is a much bigger slowdown than we expected.” ADP’s model incorporates both macro variables and employment data collected from the firms who use its payroll service, Pantheon notes, so the fact that the May number was substantially lower than Pantheon’s estimate, which is based solely on macro variables, implies that the information ADP collected from its clients was very soft. “ADP’s model is not always reliable, but this is such a big miss that we have to temper our forecast for Friday’s official number” the consultancy say “we now expect a 100K increase.”

* US NON-MANUFACTURING ISM: A solid report saw the headline rebound to 56.9 (cons 55.5, prev 55.5). The breakdown was encouraging, with activity, new orders and employment rising, although prices slipped a touch. “The report suggests service-sector growth is solid,” Goldman Sachs said. Goldman focussed on the contrasting signals on the labour market given by the ISM and the ADP data, arguing that it was placing substantially more weight on the ISM given the potentially large drag from financial variables and economic inputs in the ADP model this month.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.80 LOWER AT USD 51.68/BBL; BRENT (Q8) SETTLES USD 1.34 LOWER AT USD 60.63/BBL: The bears were in control (again) following the EIA’s inventory data release on Wednesday, which was bearish on all fronts and saw crude nosedive. Headline crude stocks printed a surprise build of 6.8mln bbls, essentially double the API figure and in contrast to the expected 0.8mln draw. In the products, gasoline built by 3.2mln bbls (exp. +0.6mln) and distillates built by 4.6mln bbls (exp. +0.5mln). Cushing stocks built by 1.8mln bbls, which analysts said was surprising given the time of year, when we are entering peak season for summer refining runs. US crude production was also reported to have increased to all-time highs at 12.4mln BPD. Unsurprisingly, crude markets legged lower on the release and extended losses.

* S&P 500 0.8% at 2826, NASDAQ-10 0.8% at 7221, Dow Jones  0.8% at 25540: SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.4%, Consumer Staples 1.1%, Energy -1.1%, Financials 0.6%, Health Care  0.7%, Industrials 1.1%, Information Technology 1.4%, Materials 0.8%, Telecommunication Services 0.1%, Utilities 2.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Salesforce.com (CRM) moved higher at the open after the firm reported earnings that beat on bottom line expectations and raised guidance higher for FY20. Brown-Forman Corp (BF.B) caught a bid after the firm also reported strong earnings, beating on the top and bottom lines. United Health Corp (UNH) was up after the healthcare provider raised its dividend. Ford (F) fell on news that Chinese subsidiary Changan Auto would be fined by Chinese regulators for violating anti-monopoly law. Boeing (BA) momentarily popped higher as news emerged that the aircraft maker is in talks with airlines from China for a 100-jet sale, but the move quickly reversed with sources stating that US-China trade discussions are complicating talks. Apple (AAPL) advanced, supported by CEO Tim Cook comments, where he said he doesn't see China targeting Apple in the trade dispute and the news that the company will ask developers to position a new "Sign on with Apple" button in iPhone and iPad apps which will be placed above rival buttons from Alphabet's Google and Facebook. Walmart (WMT) shares were up despite calls from Democratic Presidential Candidate Bernie Sanders pushing for higher wages for its workers. Campbell Soup (CPB) jumped higher after the firm posted strong earnings and raised FY guidance. Facebook (FB) lagged the market, under pressure amid news that investors are calling for Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to be replaced as chairman by an independent director.

* FX DAILY WRAP: USD was under pressure early on, as Fed’s Brainard joined the dovish chorus and ADP employment numbers came in well below expectations, with DXY moving as low as 96.80. However, over the course of the session the move reversed, as better than expected ISM non-Manufacturing data and comments from Fed’s Kaplan (typically a dove) lent back on the markets aggressive pricing of rate cuts. EUR got brief impetus from better than expected Eurozone services PMIs, but met chart hurdles at 1.1300 (vs USD), while also being plagued by more Italian-EU fiscal wrangling as the latter reiterated grounds to enact the EDP. GBP outperformed the single currency for a second day, as services PMI broke a run of sub-50 readings in the Construction and Manufacturing PMIs, and above consensus 51.0 print; meanwhile US President Trump tempered on yesterday’s comments that the NHS would be “on the table” during US/UK trade negotiations post Brexit. JPY weaker against the buck, as the latter strengthened, and risk sentiment remained relatively upbeat on the recent Fed pivot. NZD was the G10 outperformer, following hawkish remarks from RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby overnight – effectively signalling that the current level of policy accommodation is sufficient for the foreseeable future (RBNZ has an easing bias) - AUDNZD hit near 2-month lows, briefly visiting the 1.0500 handle. The EM complex was mixed. MXN started stronger as Mexican President AMLO and White House Trade Advisor seemed upbeat on the prospect of a US/Mexico deal being done in time for the latter to avoid tariffs. However, gains were capped as the White House latter walked back on some of this optimism, with downside later exacerbated as reports emerged that Mexico would be making its own demands in the talks. TRY continued to strengthen, moving below 5.7500, as oil prices sunk, the dollar remained weak and optimism remains upbeat following the recent promising inflation data. However, the risk of a further escalation in tensions between Turkey and the US remains, as the former plans to move ahead with its purchase of Russian S-400s; albeit, there is optimism that US President Trump and Turkey President Erdogan might see eye to eye in their meeting at the G20 Summit later this month. BRL was weaker as Services and Composite PMI fell into contractionary territory. RUB was also weaker, taking its cue from the crude complex; on which note NOK also fell, with EURNOK advancing above recent resistance at 9.8000.

subject: US Senate Finance Chief Grassley predicts that the US will not impose the Mexican tariffs; says Mexico is going into talks with a "long list of things" to offer to avert the tariffs; believes an announcement on a deal could be made on a tariffs deal
Daily FX Wrap: Buck bears acknowledge ADP, but act on more dovish Fed intimations
content:
USD

The DXY is clinging to the 97.000 pivot as a relatively upbeat non-manufacturing US ISM offsets some of the negativity from a vastly weaker than forecast ADP tally as a precursor to Friday’s BLS report. However, latest comments from the Fed are keeping the Dollar depressed overall and the index on an incrementally lower trajectory as Brainard echoed chair Powell with a pledge to adjust policy to maintain growth if required, while even Evans sounded more willing to discuss an insurance cut given some concerns about soft inflation. Moreover, the latter added it would be prudent to review the current monetary policy stance this month, and on each occasion that the FOMC meet, which in turn puts additional emphasis on the upcoming Beige Book. DXY currently holding within a 97.154-96.741 range with nearest chart support and resistance seen at 96.745 and 97.030 in the context of closing levels.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has been the major performer and extended gains to 0.6665 and virtually 1.0500 vs its US and Aussie rivals at best following comparatively hawkish rhetoric from RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby overnight – effectively signalling that the current level of policy accommodation is sufficient for the foreseeable future. Conversely, Aud/Usd failed to maintain its post-RBA recovery and short squeeze momentum amidst speculation that a back-to-back ease in July could be more aggressive (ie ½ point this 25 bp) and recoiled from just over 0.70000 to 0.6980, with hefty options and chart resistance also hampering the Aussie.

GBP 

The next best G10 currency, but only partly on UK specifics as the services PMI broke a run of sub-50 readings with an above consensus 51.0 print. Cable consolidated its rebound and reached 1.2740+ peaks at one stage, with a helping hand from the aforementioned weak Greenback, while Eur/Gbp pulled back from circa 0.8878 to sub-0.8850, but again at least partially on relative underperformance in the single currency.

CHF

Another beneficiary at the expense of others, as Usd/Chf breached the psychological 0.9900 level within a 0.9930-0.9855 range and Eur/Chf retreated from near 1.1200 to around 1.1140 as broad risk sentiment soured amidst a steeper reversal in oil prices, which also undermined the Loonie and Nokkie predictably (Usd/Cad back up around 1.3400 vs almost 1.3360 and Eur/Nok close to 9.8150 from 9.7220 or thereabouts at the other extreme).

EUR/JPY

Both fairly volatile vs the Buck between 1.1250-1.1305 and 108.37-107.82 respectively as the Euro got brief impetus from better than expected Eurozone services PMIs, but met chart hurdles around the big figure and was also plagued by more Italian-EU fiscal wrangling as the latter reiterated grounds to enact the EDP. Meanwhile, the Yen was more prone to swings in the risk tone as usual alongside changes in US Treasury and JGB yield differentials.

EM

The Peso grabbed some of the regional headlines on the back of more positive reports about the prospects for a Mexican-US deal before next Monday’s tariff deadline, and in particular from President AMLO who expressed optimism that an accord could be reached as soon as today. Usd/Mxn tested 14.5000 vs 19.6700+ at the high, and with extra encouragement from US Trade advisor Navarro who suggested that higher import taxes may not have to be imposed.

Talking Crude: US energy inventories, another roadblock for bulls
content:
• Energy markets have been trading choppy on Wednesday, but ultimately lower following the API inventory data, with WTI consolidating around the USD 53/bbl level. The API release was bearish on all fronts, where US crude stocks built 3.55mln bbls (exp. -0.8mln), distillates built a chunky 6.31mln (exp. +0.6mln), gasoline built 2.70mln (exp. +0.5mln). Cushing, Oklahoma built by 1.41mln bbls, it is worth noting that the weather-related pipeline closures last week were speculated to have caused build ups at Cushing. Participants will now be looking to see confirmation in the official EIA inventory release later in the session.
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak and Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih are to meet on June 10th, which could be an attempt to find a consensus on the debated dates for the OPEC+ meeting. Although Russian officials had recently spoke in favour of extending OPEC+ supply cuts, the energy ministry may face some pushback from producers. Russia’s Rosneft recently said that it would seek compensation from the Russian government if the supply cuts are extended. Additionally, Russia’s Gazprom Neft said on earlier in the session that Russian producers are ready to boost output quickly if OPEC+ decide to do so, and that itself can raise output by 50k BPD in the next two months and 70k BPD by year-end.
  • SocGen sees Brent rising from current levels to USD 70/bbl in the second half of this year, “we believe the balance of risks is now skewed marginally to the upside.” The bank cites the likelihood of supply cuts being extended, especially given the recent sell off in crude markets; in addition the analysts note with Libya close to maximum output, there are risks this would be cut if the civil war escalates, as well as the sustained Venezuelan and Iranian export glut.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 5th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

3M (MMM) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) is to sell its gas and flame detection business to Teledyne (TDY) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) for USD 230mln.

Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) CEO Tim Cook commented that he doesn't see China targeting Apple in the trade dispute. Elsewhere, the company will ask developers to position a new "Sign on with Apple" button in iPhone and iPad apps which will be placed above rival buttons from Alphabet's Google and Facebook, a move analysts are calling significant because users often select the default or top option on apps.

Microsoft (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) showed off a dual-screen Surface prototype, codenamed Centaurus, at a recent event, according to the Verge. Reportedly, the technology giant is also working on a smaller "pocketable" Surface device codenamed Andromeda, although the company has reportedly halted its work on this device in favour of the larger device.

UnitedHealth Group (UNH) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) board has increased quarterly dividend by 20% to USD 1.08/shr.

Walmart (WMT) ( Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) - Democratic Presidential Candidate Bernie Sanders is set to push for USD 15 per hour minimum wage at Walmart at its annual shareholder meeting on Wednesday.

NASDAQ 100

Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) - The FTC has begun to question some of Amazon's competitors about the e-commerce giant's business practices, reports Vox, though it has not yet officially launched a formal investigation. Reportedly, there are three lines of questioning related to Amazon’s business practises, including: queries related to the pricing structure of Amazon's logistics service, how the company competes against its own sellers and queries related to Amazon Prime's bundling of services.

Comcast (CMCSA) (Communication Services/Cable & Satellite) subsidiary Dreamwork Animation announced Jurassic World: Camp Cretaceous, an animated action-adventure series which is set to debut globally on Netflix (NFLX) (Communications Services/Entertainment) in 2020. This forms part of an ongoing multi-year agreement between the two co.s to produce original animated kids and family programming.

Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - Some pension fund investors are calling for Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to be replaced as chairman by an independent director, as reported by the New York Post. At Facebook’s recent annual shareholder meeting, 68% of investors voted to back a proposal to strip Zuckerberg of his role as chairman. Elsewhere, Business Insider reported that three senior Facebook security workers are out amid investigations into finances and misconduct allegations.

Google (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) will appeal a USD 1.7bln fine from the European Commission, where it stands accused of stifling competition in the online advertising industry.

NXPI Semiconductors (NXPI) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) and Momenta have announced a strategic collaboration on automotive-grade Driver Monitoring Solutions which will aim to provide solutions on systems that monitor driver attentiveness. The collaboration will aim to enable the mass deployment of DMS applications by car makers.

S&P 500

Brown-Forman Corp (BF.B) (Consumer Staples/Distillers & Vintners) (USD) Q1 19 EPS 0.33 (exp. 0.30), revenue 0.744bln (exp. 0.76bln). FY20 EPS view 1.75-1.85 (exp. 1.82).

Campbell Soup Co (CPB) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) (USD) reports Q1 19 EPS 0.56 (exp. 0.47), revenue 2.39bln (exp. 2.36bln), raises FY EPS view to 2.50-2.55 (exp. 2.47), reduces FY revenue view to 9.08-9.13bln (exp. 9.94bln).

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) - During an interview on CNBC's Mad Money, CFO Jack Hartung said “Mexican tariff impact will be very manageable”.

Eli Lilly (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that the FDA has approved its Emgality drug for the treatment of episodic cluster headache in adults. This follows the drugs approval for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults in September 2018.

Ford Motor Co (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) - China's market regulator fined Ford's main Chinese joint venture, Changan Ford, 162.8 million yuan for the alleged violation of antitrust laws. The State Administration for Market Regulation said Changan Ford had breached the law by setting a minimum resale price for its cars in the Chinese municipality of Chongqing since 2013.

General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) - The White House has denied General Motors’ request for an exemption to a 25% U.S. tariff on its Chinese-manufactured Buick Envision SUV.

Laboratory Corp. of America Holding (LH) (Health Care/Health Care Services) says 7.7mln of its customers may be impacted by a data breach affecting rival firm Quest Diagnostics (DGX) (Health Care/Health Care Services), a breach which may have exposed bank/credit card data.

Salesforce.Com Inc (CRM) (Information Technology/Software) Q1 20 (USD): adj. EPS 0.93 (exp. 0.61), Revenue 3.74bln (exp. 3.68bln). Raises FY20 adj. EPS view 2.88-2.90 (exp. 2.67), raises FY20 Revenue view 16.10bln-16.25bln (exp. 16.12bln). Sees Q2 adj. EPS 0.46-0.47 (exp. 0.66). Q1 Billings 2.71bln; Q1 Cloud Revenue 1.07bln.

T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communication Services /Wireless Telecommunication Services) is reportedly tapping Goldman Sachs (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) to help sell assets as it aims to gain approval for its proposed merger with Sprint (S) (Communication Services /Wireless Telecommunication Services).

Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) (Financials/Diversified Banks) said it will narrow its philanthropic focus towards three causes including affordable housing, in which it will donate USD 1bln to housing over the next few years.

OTHER

Fiat Chrysler’s (FCA IM, FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) proposed merger with Renault (RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) will be discussed by the latter’s board again today, after the board had previously said it needed more time to consider the proposal. 

GameStop (GME) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) Q1 19 (USD) EPS 0.07 (exp. -0.03), Revenue 1.5bln (exp. 1.64bln). Sees FY19 comparable store sales down by 5% to 10%.

Russian oil companies are ready to boost crude output quickly if OPEC+ decide to do so, according to RIA citing Gazprom Neft
analysis_details: • Sources post-JMMC noted that the Saudi energy minister and his Russian counterpart discussed two possible options. The first scenario would see an elimination of over compliance currently over 150%, equating to an output cuts just under 2mln BPD, according to calculations. This would mean a continuation of the current deal and an increase in production of around 0.8mln BPD. The second scenario would see an ease of the agreed cuts to 0.9mln BPD from 1.2mln BPD. Nonetheless, oil output data will be closely watched in the coming weeks for hints of which way OPEC and its allies may sway as they convene in Vienna on June 25/26.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 5th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] are firmer but notably not as buoyed as the Asia-Pac session was overnight
  • In FX, the USD remains weak with the DXY back below the 97.0 handle to the benefit of all (ex-JPY) G10 counterparts
  • European Commission are to instigate infringement processes against the Italian Government due to their fiscal policy
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Composite and Services PMI, US ADP, ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI, Fed’s Clarida, Evans, Rosengren, Bostic

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher as the region took impetus from the strength in the US where sentiment was buoyed after comments from Fed Chair Powell spurred hopes of a rate cut. This saw Wall St notch its biggest gain since early-January with the Nasdaq the frontrunner as tech outperformed, while all sectors in the S&P 500 closed in the green and the DJIA rallied by over 500 points. ASX 200 (+0.4%) gained in which tech led the upside and with risk appetite supported by the recent rate cut by the RBA, as well its openness to further reductions. Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) surged as Japanese exporters cheered a weaker currency and with SoftBank shares boosted as it expects to book a profit of around JPY 1.2tln on the partial sale of its Alibaba stake. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) conformed to the positive global risk tone but with gains capped by disappointing Chinese Caixin PMI data and a substantial liquidity drain of CNY 210bln by the PBoC, while trade concerns lingered after China issued a warning against travelling to the US and held a meeting on rare earths where experts recommended greater controls on exports of the metals. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices underpinned on the back of Fed Chair Powell’s dovishness and as Japanese 10yr yields slipped to their lowest in around 3 years.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 210bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8903 (Prev. 6.8822)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (May) 52.7 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.5); 3-month low. (Newswires) Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (May) 51.5 (Prev. 52.7)

Chinese President Xi said China's economy is improving and that China has ample room to use policies to deal with risks. Xi also commented that China's economy will have enough factors of support to maintain stable, health and sustainable development, while he added that domestic consumption remained the main driver of growth. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin will meet with PBoC Governor Yi Gang at the G20 Finance meeting in Japan, while there were separate reports that G20 finance ministers will tell G20 this week that resolving global trade tensions has become the highest priority and that any further global economic slowdown will call for coordinated response. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department made recommendations to boost production of domestic critical minerals and other measures such as low rates, loan guarantees, tax credits and capital gains tax exemptions. The report also recommended expanding cooperation with Canada, Australia, EU, Japan and South Korea on critical minerals exploration, processing and recycling. (Newswires)

Ford’s China JV was fined CNY 162.8mln by Chinese regulators for violating anti-monopoly law. (Newswires)

China’s Embassy in Canada said PM Trudeau's comments on Chinese human rights represent a flagrant interference in China's internal affairs and China has made stern representations to Canada following Trudeau's criticism of Beijing's human rights record. (Newswires)

World Bank lowers global growth forecast for this year to 2.6% from 2.9%. (Newswires)

US

 

US President Trump stated that US Senate Minority leader Schumer gave Mexico bad advice in his suggestion that the tariffs on Mexico is a bluff, while Trump added it is 'no bluff!'. Elsewhere, US Senate Majority leader McConnell said there is "not much support" from Republicans for tariffs on Mexico and hopes they can be avoided via talks with the Mexican delegation, while a US administration official said US-Mexico talks will be held at the White House today around 1500EDT or 1600EDT. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweets that 'House Republicans support the President on Tariffs with Mexico all the way, & that makes any measure the President takes on the Border totally Veto proof'. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said he wants to see if trade tensions ease before considering a rate cut and suggested that it pays to be patient and vigilant right now. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson warned Conservative MPs that a Brexit delay means defeat and that the Conservative Party faces “extinction” if Britain is not out of the EU by October 31st. (Telegraph)

US President Trump backtracked regarding the NHS being part of a future US-UK trade deal and stated that he doesn’t see it being on the table as the health service was something that would not be consider part of trade, which was in contrast to a prior suggestion of including the NHS in trade discussions. (Guardian)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (May) 51.0 vs. Exp. 50.6 (Prev. 50.4)

- IHS Markit state that the data suggests the UK economy is close to stagnation

- Modest increase in business activity, New work rises for the first time since December 2018

- Slowest rise in input costs for 12 months

The European Commission are to begin infringement process against the Italian government due to its fiscal policy, the letter states that Italian polices have hurt confidence and have contributed to the economic slowdown. With the European Commission stating that the launch of EDP on Italy is justified by their growing debt. Prior to this, it was reported that yesterday Italian Deputy PM’s Salvini and Di Maio discussed the option of breaching the EU’s 3% budget deficit rule. Additionally, Italian League Economic Chief Borghi stated that PM Conte and Economy Minister Tria need to take a hard line on EU budget talks Separately, Italy are reportedly committing to EUR 3.5bln in annual savings. (Newswires/La Repubblica/Corriere Della Sera/Stampa)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (May) 52.9 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.5)

- EU Markit Comp Final PMI (May) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.6 (Prev. 51.6)

- German Markit Services Final PMI (May) 55.4 vs. Exp. 55 (Prev. 55)

- German Markit Comp Final PMI (May) 52.6 vs. Exp. 52.4 (Prev. 52.4)

- French Markit Services PMI (May) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.7 (Prev. 51.7)

- French Markit Comp PMI (May) 51.2 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.3)

EQUITIES

Major European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%] are firmer, although somewhat more subdued than their Asia-Pac counterparts, which were boosted by Wall Street printing its largest daily gain since early-January. Sectors are somewhat mixed, with the Tech sector the notable outperformer, despite yesterday’s FAANG driven underperformance in tech names; where the sector lagged heavily for much of the session. Separately, but potentially of note for Tech names; TSMC Chairman Liu stated that the US’s move to ban US companies from doing business with Huawei is to have a short-term impact on TSMC, though the Co’s outlook remains unchanged, which may have provided some impetus to the European IT names. This morning’s most notable move is Provident Financial (+16.4%) on the back of Non-Standard Finance (-2.7%) stating that they are not going ahead with the hostile takeover. Also, in the green and towards the top of the Stoxx 600 are Norsk Hydro (+3.6%) after posting stronger than expected earnings; however, the Co. state that they expect to see payments relating to the cyber-attack in their Q3 earnings. Meanwhile, Saipem (+4.8%) shares spiked higher after announcing a new EPC contract for Anadarko Mozambique project, in which the Co. will have a share of around USD 6bln. Finally, Hikma Pharmaceuticals (-0.8%) are in negative territory as they are set to be removed from the FTSE 100.

FX

NZD/AUD - Some divergence down under as RBNZ Deputy Governor Hawkesby intimates that rates may remain on hold for a while if not considerably longer in contrast to RBA Governor Lowe who inferred that more easing could be in the offing in addition to Tuesday’s 25 bp OCR cut. Hence, the Aud/Nzd cross has recoiled further from circa 1.0600 and through 1.0550, while the Kiwi is leading G10 gains vs a soggy Greenback after Fed chair Powell promised to support the US economy against a more pronounced slowdown yesterday. Nzd/Usd has tested resistance and offers around 0.6950, as Aud/Usd continues its rebound from pre-RBA lows to just over 0.7000 and into a heavy option expiry zone spanning 0.7005 to 0.7025 (1.7 bn). Note also, the Aussie needs to clear Fib resistance at 0.6995 convincingly and faces congested technical resistance between 0.7033-35 in the form of the 55 DMA and another Fib.

USD - The aforementioned Dollar weakness has pushed the DXY back down below 97.000 and sub-the 100 DMA at 96.980 to a fresh 96.915 low amidst widespread losses vs major currency counterparts and EMs, bar the Yen and Rand. Technically, 96.745 is the next support level and fundamentally the focus switches to ADP ahead of Friday’s NFP, services surveys (Markit PMI and ISM) and more Fed speak.

EUR/GBP/CAD/CHF - As noted above, all beneficiaries of the Buck’s demise, but with the single currency and Pound also gleaning some traction via better than expected services PMIs, on balance. Indeed, Eur/Usd has now surpassed the 100 DMA (1.1276) having narrowly missed the equivalent level on Tuesday and is eyeing 1.1300, while Cable seems more assured on the 1.2700 handle, albeit still lagging in Eur/Gbp cross terms within a 0.8855-80 range. Elsewhere, the Loonie has overcome 1.3400 and is filling hefty buying interest layered from 1.3370 to 1.3360, with the 100 DMA sitting just under 1.3350 at 1.3348, and the Franc has rebounded towards 0.9900 but underperforming vs the Euro in broad 1.1300-1.1250 parameters.

JPY - In contrast to its major peers, the Yen has been undermined by the ongoing recovery in broad risk sentiment and is retesting recent 108.30+ lows vs the Dollar with decent expiries also within close proximity at 108.20-30 (1 bn) and 108.50-55 (1.1 bn).

EM - While most of the region takes advantage of the Dollar’s downturn, more downbeat SA macro developments have hit the Rand and propped up Usd/Zar within 14.8240-6260 boundaries. The bad news kicked off with a sub-50 services PMI and continued via weaker business sentiment, while the ANC party’s ally has joined forces to back a wider SARB policy mandate prompting a dismissive response from the Bank itself.

Australian Real GDP (Q1) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires) Australian Real GDP (Q1) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 2.3%)

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said RBNZ central view is for interest rates to remain broadly around current levels for the foreseeable future and that the bank needs to be prepared to adapt to changing conditions to meet its objectives. (Newswires)

South African Communist Party, seen as a key ANC ally, state that the SARB's mandate must explicitly include employment and growth targeting and the act pertaining to the bank should be amended, subsequently SARB Governor Kganyago states that the constitutional mandate of the bank is price stability; and their Finance Minister says no-one is discussing changes to the SARB’s mandate. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Notwithstanding claims from Italian PM Conte that the country’s finances will be more healthy than implied by the first half of 2019 and Rome will do all it can to avoid EDP measures, BTPs are succumbing to another bout of investor angst with the Sep19 future now down through 129.00 and almost a full point below the 129.78 high. This has given Bunds a boost from a new 170.85 Eurex low in wake of better than expected Eurozone services PMIs, but Gilts have rebounded further from their deeper 129.67 Liffe base despite a UK services beat. Elsewhere, the US Treasury curve remains steeper after yesterday’s assurances from Fed’s Powell that policy will be tweaked as needed, ie loosened in the case of a more pronounced slowdown, as the focus turns to ADP, non-manufacturing PMI/ISM and another raft of Fed speakers.

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.7%) and Brent (-0.6%) prices are back on the decline as a surprise build in last night’s API exacerbated the recent downside seen amidst demand concerns. Stockpiles last week increased by 3.5mln barrels vs. an expected decline of 800k barrels. On the OPEC front, Russian Energy Minister Novak will be meeting his Saudi counterpart, Al-Falih, on June 10th to potentially discuss a date for the OPEC/OPEC+ meeting with no confirmation as of yet to whether it will take place at the end of June or early July. News-flow has been light for the complex thus far, with traders now eyeing the release of the weekly DoE crude stocks data in which the headline is expected to draw by 849k barrels. Elsewhere, Gold (+0.9%) is holding onto a bulk of its recent gains amid the weaker post-Powell USD whilst copper is set to notch a third straight day of gains on the back of a receding Buck, whilst alumina prices declined due to a demand halt as traders paused on spot purchases amid high prices.

Russian Energy Minister Novak and Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih are to meet on June 10th, according to a statement. (Newswires)

EU's Moscovici says the European Commission's door remains open to avoid disciplinary procedure against Italy

content: In keeping with the renewed bid elsewhere, Gilts are paring losses following Tuesday’s retracement and extended gains to 28 ticks from an initial 20 ticks before running out of steam ahead of 130.00, also in line with some loss of momentum in Bunds and US Treasuries. However, the Short Sterling strip remains firm between 0.5 and 3 ticks above yesterday’s closing levels in wake of comments from Fed chair Powell that underpinned rate cut expectations without explicitly signalling a shift in stance, and as attention turns towards the last of the May PMIs in the form of services. Note, BoE’s Ramsden stuck to the Libor script, as expected. Back to Liffe, the 10 year benchmark is holding within a 129.91-74 range vs its previous 129.63 close.

Bunds: inching closer to next upside chart target
content: It’s a slow grind after another relatively modest pull-back, but the core Eurozone bond appears destined if not intent on breaking fresh bullish ground and testing the 171.32 level that represents nearest technical resistance from the new 171.27 contract peak. Similarly, -25 bp in yield terms seems almost inevitable or too tempting ahead of services PMIs, PPI and tomorrow’s ECB meeting as oil prices continue to decline and BTPs are hampered by Italian budget issues that look set to trigger EDP measures. Note, ECB’s Praet is on today’s agenda, but should refrain from anything policy related so close to the aforementioned policy convene.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

5th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher as the region took impetus from the strength in US where sentiment was buoyed after comments from Fed Chair Powell spurred hopes of a rate cut. This saw Wall St notch its biggest gain since early-January with the Nasdaq the frontrunner as tech outperformed, while all sectors in the S&P 500 closed in the green and the DJIA rallied by over 500 points. ASX 200 (+0.5%) gained in which tech led the upside and with risk appetite supported by the recent rate cut by the RBA, as well its openness to further reductions. Meanwhile, Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) surged as Japanese exporters cheered a weaker currency and with SoftBank shares boosted as it expects to book a profit of around JPY 1.2tln on the partial sale of its Alibaba stake. Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) conformed to the positive global risk tone but with gains capped by disappointing Chinese Caixin PMI data and a substantial liquidity drain of CNY 210bln by the PBoC, while trade concerns lingered after China issued a warning against travelling to the US and held a meeting on rare earths where experts recommended greater controls on exports of the metals

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 5th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices were higher as the region took impetus from Wall St. posting its largest daily gain since early-January
  • Italian Deputy PM’s Salvini and Di Maio have reached an agreement to work together
  • In FX the DXY dropped towards the 97.0 level following Fed comments; to the benefit of most G10 counterparts
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ & US Composite and Services PMI, UK Services PMI, US ADP, ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI, BoE’s Ramsden, Fed’s Clarida, Evans, Rosengren, Bostic

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher as the region took impetus from the strength in the US where sentiment was buoyed after comments from Fed Chair Powell spurred hopes of a rate cut. This saw Wall St notch its biggest gain since early-January with the Nasdaq the frontrunner as tech outperformed, while all sectors in the S&P 500 closed in the green and the DJIA rallied by over 500 points. ASX 200 (+0.5%) gained in which tech led the upside and with risk appetite supported by the recent rate cut by the RBA, as well its openness to further reductions. Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) surged as Japanese exporters cheered a weaker currency and with SoftBank shares boosted as it expects to book a profit of around JPY 1.2tln on the partial sale of its Alibaba stake. Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) conformed to the positive global risk tone but with gains capped by disappointing Chinese Caixin PMI data and a substantial liquidity drain of CNY 210bln by the PBoC, while trade concerns lingered after China issued a warning against travelling to the US and held a meeting on rare earths where experts recommended greater controls on exports of the metals. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with prices underpinned on the back of Fed Chair Powell’s dovishness and as Japanese 10yr yields slipped to their lowest in around 3 years.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 210bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8903 (Prev. 6.8822)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (May) 52.7 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.5); 3-month low. (Newswires) Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (May) 51.5 (Prev. 52.7)

Chinese President Xi said China's economy is improving and that China has ample room to use policies to deal with risks. Xi also commented that China's economy will have enough factors of support to maintain stable, health and sustainable development, while he added that domestic consumption remained the main driver of growth. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin will meet with PBoC Governor Yi Gang at the G20 Finance meeting in Japan, while there were separate reports that G20 finance ministers will tell G20 this week that resolving global trade tensions has become the highest priority and that any further global economic slowdown will call for coordinated response. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department made recommendations to boost production of domestic critical minerals and other measures such as low rates, loan guarantees, tax credits and capital gains tax exemptions. The report also recommended expanding cooperation with Canada, Australia, EU, Japan and South Korea on critical minerals exploration, processing and recycling. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said Beijing is willing to negotiate but is now convinced fair talks are impossible without a fight and that China realised they were naive before in believing that the trade talks could yield results. (Twitter)

Ford’s China JV was fined CNY 162.8mln by Chinese regulators for violating anti-monopoly law. (Newswires)

Canada Agriculture Ministry has been informed that China Customs agency will be raising inspections on Canadian meat imports and that China said the extra checks are being taken because of African swine fever and smuggling worries. In other news, China’s Embassy in Canada said PM Trudeau's comments on Chinese human rights represent a flagrant interference in China's internal affairs and China has made stern representations to Canada following Trudeau's criticism of Beijing's human rights record. (Newswires)

World Bank lowered global growth forecast for this year to 2.6% from 2.9%. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson warned Conservative MPs that a Brexit delay means defeat and that the Conservative Party faces “extinction” if Britain is not out of the EU by October 31st. (Telegraph)

Separately, 3 MP’s (Rishi Sunak, Robert Jenrick & Oliver Dowden) who are seen as rising stars in the Tory party have given their support to Boris Johnson’s PM bid; meaning Johnson has 40 public endorsements compared with Environment Secretary Gove’s 26. (Times)

US President Trump backtracked regarding the NHS being part of a future US-UK trade deal and stated that he doesn’t see it being on the table as the health service was something that would not be consider part of trade, which was in contrast to a prior suggestion of including the NHS in trade discussions. (Guardian)

Italy Deputy PMs Di Maio and Salvini reached an agreement to work together and Di Maio said he intends to govern for four more years and that Italy needs stability. (Newswires)

FX

 

DXY weakened towards 97.00 following percieved dovish comments by Fed Chair Powell. This lifted the greenback’s major counterparts with EUR/USD mildly supported by optimism after the Italian political situation stabilised in which its Deputy PMs reached an agreement to work together, and with GBP/USD back at the 1.2700 handle. The heightened risk appetite lifted JPY-crosses although USD/JPY failed to benefit due to the USD weakness and languished around the 108.00 level. Elsewhere, antipodeans remained firm due to their high-beta statuses with NZD/USD underpinned after RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said the bank’s central view is for interest rates to remain broadly around current levels for the foreseeable future and after mixed Australian GDP data for Q1 failed to dent AUD/USD which tested the 0.7000 level to the upside.

Australian Real GDP (Q1) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires) Australian Real GDP (Q1) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 2.3%)

RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said RBNZ central view is for interest rates to remain broadly around current levels for the foreseeable future and that the bank needs to be prepared to adapt to changing conditions to meet its objectives. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with overnight trade relatively quiet across commodities amid several closures including the Asia periphery and across the Middle East for holidays. Nonetheless, oil prices were subdued in which WTI crude futures languished near the USD 53.00/bbl level following a surprise build in headline API crude stockpiles and with the components also bearish. Elsewhere, gold flatlined near 3-month highs as the softer greenback provided a platform, while copper was steady as the prior day’s momentum stalled amid ongoing trade uncertainty.

API Crude Inventories 3.55mln vs. Exp. -0.8mln (Prev. -5.27mln) barrels. (Newswires)

US

Yields started off the session higher, though the bear-flattening gave way to bear-steepening as markets digested a heavy slate of Fedspeak. Voter Evans got us underway, hinting that there could be rate cuts as part of the Fed’s reaction function to trade wars, a sentiment underscored by Chair Powell later, and Vice Chair Clarida after that. The rise in short-end yields was supported by no mention of rate cuts from Powell, some analysts reasoned, while the longer-end’s rise in yields was taking its cue from stocks rallying. In terms of Fed pricing, The probability that rates would remain at 2.25-2.50% by year-end actually rose a touch (to 6% from 2%), according to CME Fedwatch; however, pricing for a June rate cut increased by around 7.5ppts (to 27.5%), and pricing for a July rate cut rose from 53.1% to 66.5%. US T-note future (M9) settled 9+ lower at 126-19.

US President Trump stated that US Senate Minority leader Schumer gave Mexico bad advice in his suggestion that the tariffs on Mexico is a bluff, while Trump added it is 'no bluff!'. Elsewhere, US Senate Majority leader McConnell said there is "not much support" from Republicans for tariffs on Mexico and hopes they can be avoided via talks with the Mexican delegation, while a US administration official said US-Mexico talks will be held at the White House today around 1500EDT or 1600EDT. (Newswires)

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said Fed would put in appropriate policy if growth is slower than the Fed expects but also commented that the US economy is in a good place. Clarida also doesn't see tariffs as inflationary and rather a one-off price increase with the effects small so far. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said he wants to see if trade tensions ease before considering a rate cut and suggested that it pays to be patient and vigilant right now. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain after Fed Chair Powell’s comments inspired Wall St's best performance since early January
content:
Asia equity markets are higher as the region takes impetus from the performance in US where sentiment was buoyed after comments from Fed Chair Powell spurred hopes of a rate cut. This saw Wall St notch its biggest gain since early-January with the Nasdaq the frontrunner as tech outperformed, while all sectors in the S&P 500 closed in the green and the DJIA rallied by over 500 points. ASX 200 (+0.8%) benefits from the firm lead with tech leading the upside and as the recent rate cut by the RBA as well its openness to further reductions underpins sentiment. Meanwhile, Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) surged as Japanese exporters cheer a weaker currency and with SoftBank shares also boosted as it expects to book a profit of around JPY 1.2tln on the partial sale of its Alibaba stake. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) conform to the positive global risk tone but with gains in the mainland capped by disappointing Chinese Caixin PMI data and a substantial liquidity drain of CNY 210bln by the PBoC, as well the increased trade tensions after China issued a warning against travelling to the US and held a meeting on rare earths where experts recommended greater controls on exports of the metals.

In FX markets, the DXY weakened towards 97.00 following the dovish comments by Fed Chair Powell that the Fed will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion and he sees a much higher likelihood rates will fall to the effective lower bound in a downturn, as well as the likelihood crisis era tools may be needed again. This lifted the greenback’s major counterparts with EUR/USD mildly supported by optimism after the Italian political situation stabilised in which its Deputy PMs reached an agreement to work together, and with GBP/USD back at the 1.2700 handle. The heightened risk appetite lifted JPY-crosses although USD/JPY has failed to benefit due to the USD weakness and languishes around the 108.00 level. Elsewhere, antipodeans remain firm with NZD/USD underpinned after RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby said the central view is for interest rates to remain broadly around current levels for the foreseeable future and as mixed Australian GDP data for Q1 failed to dent AUD/USD which tests the 0.7000 level to the upside.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with prices underpinned on the back of the Fed Chair Powell’s dovishness and as Japanese 10yr yields slip to their lowest in nearly 3 years.

Trade

China issued a warning against travelling to the US in which it warned over the threat of gun violence and robberies, with the warning to remain in effect until the end of the year. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry said it is clear that every set-back in US trade talks was due to the US breaking consensus, while it added that China has the resolve and ability to defend their interests and rights. However, there were later comments from MOFCOM which urged dialogue and negotiations to resolve frictions and hopes US stops its wrong doings and meets China halfway. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said Beijing is willing to negotiate but is now convinced fair talks are impossible without a fight and that China realised they were naive before in believing that the trade talks could yield results. Furthermore, the China Global Times Editor suggested that the positive image of the US has been ruined and the Chinese now deeply believe key US officials are keen on destroying China’s development capability. (Twitter)

US Treasury Official said Treasury Secretary Mnuchin will see a Chinese delegation at the G20 meeting but cannot confirm if a bilateral meeting of the two countries will take place. There were also separate reports that G20 finance ministers will tell G20 this week that resolving global trade tensions has become the highest priority and that any further global economic slowdown will call for coordinated response. (Newswires)

China's NDRC has reportedly held rare earths meeting with industry experts in which experts recommended greater controls on exports of the metals such as a centralized system to manage their mining and processing. In related news, the US Commerce Department made recommendations to boost production of domestic critical minerals, such as low rates, loan guarantees, tax credits and capital gains tax exemptions. The report also recommends expanding cooperation with Canada, Australia, EU, Japan and South Korea on critical minerals exploration, processing and recycling. (Newswires)

 

Other News - Former HKMA Chief Yam sees China’s government keeping CNY at 7.00 vs. USD and expects China to avoid currency depreciation, while Yam is concerned trade war may expand to the financial sector. (Newswires)
